data.title: GDP
data.content: Next week, the Fed's interest rate decision will take center stage. Other key highlights in the US include retail sales, PCE prices, personal income and spending, the final estimate of GDP growth, industrial production, manufacturing and services PMIs, building permits, housing starts, and existing home sales. Globally, China will release industrial production, retail sales, jobless rate, housing prices, and loan prime rates. In the UK, the BoE's policy decision, inflation figures, retail sales, and jobs report will draw attention. Japan will feature the BoJ's interest rate decision, inflation and foreign trade data. Meanwhile, interest rate decisions are also expected in Mexico, the Philippines, Sweden, Norway, Indonesia, and Thailand. Canada will release inflation data, Germany will publish the Ifo business climate index, and ZEW economic sentiment; and the Euro Area will report trade and PMI figures.
data.summary: Next week, the Fed's interest rate decision will take center stage. Other key highlights in the US include retail sales, PCE prices, personal income and spending, the final estimate of GDP growth, industrial production, manufacturing and services PMIs, building permits, housing starts, and existing home sales. Globally, China will release industrial production, retail sales, jobless rate, housing prices, and loan prime rates. In the UK, the BoE's policy decision, inflation figures, retail sales, and jobs report will draw attention. Japan will feature the BoJ's interest rate decision, inflation and foreign trade data. Meanwhile, interest rate decisions are also expected in Mexico, the Philippines, Sweden, Norway, Indonesia, and Thailand. Canada will release inflation data, Germany will publish the Ifo business climate index, and ZEW economic sentiment; and the Euro Area will report trade and PMI figures.

data.title: Stock Market
data.content: In afternoon trading, the S&P 500 and Nasdaq were hovering around the flatline, while the Dow fell more than 50 points, remaining on track for its longest losing streak since 2020 at seven sessions. Declines in tech giants Nvidia (-2.4%), Meta (-1.7%), and Amazon (-0.7%) weighed heavily on the Nasdaq. However, Broadcom soared over 20% to reach a $1 trillion market cap, fueled by a 220% surge in annual AI-related revenue, beating expectations. This momentum also lifted semiconductor peers, with Marvell (+8.2%) and Taiwan Semiconductor (+4.1%) gaining strongly. The broader market reflected mixed performance, as concerns about the Federal Reserve's upcoming policy decision and economic conditions capped gains. For the week, the S&P 500 was on course for a 0.7% decline, the Dow for a steeper 1.8% drop, and the Nasdaq for marginal losses, highlighting the challenges faced by equities amid lingering economic uncertainty.

data.title: Stock Market
data.content: US stocks advanced on Friday, with the Nasdaq gaining 0.8% to reach a new record high, fueled by investor enthusiasm for artificial intelligence and the tech sector. The rally was driven by Broadcom’s impressive 19% surge following stronger-than-expected earnings and a remarkable 220% increase in annual AI-related revenue, underscoring soaring demand for AI chips. This upbeat report boosted other semiconductor stocks, with Nvidia (1.2%) and Micron Technology (2.7%) also advancing. Broadcom’s robust outlook fueled confidence in AI’s continued role as a key growth driver, helping the Nasdaq edge toward its fourth straight weekly gain. Meanwhile, the S&P 500 and Dow Jones rebounded slightly but remained on track for weekly losses of around 0.3% and 1.3%, respectively, as lingering concerns over broader economic conditions and next week’s Federal Reserve policy decision capped gains. Traders expect a Fed rate cut but will focus on guidance for potential cuts in early 2025.
data.summary: US stocks advanced on Friday, with the Nasdaq gaining 0.8% to reach a new record high, fueled by investor enthusiasm for artificial intelligence and the tech sector. data.title: Stock Market
data.content: US stock futures signaled gains at Friday’s open, with S&P 500 futures up 0.4%, Nasdaq futures jumping 0.9%, and Dow Jones futures adding around 60 points, recovering from the previous day's losses. Broadcom shares surged 18% in premarket trading after reporting earnings that exceeded expectations and a 220% surge in annual AI revenue. The company also projected robust demand for its AI chips. Other AI-related chipmakers were also in the green premarket, including Nvidia (+1.8%), AMD (+1.6%), and Micron Technology (+2.4%). For the week, the S&P 500 is down 0.6%, the Dow Jones has lost 1.6%, while the Nasdaq has edged up 0.2%. Traders now shift their focus to next week’s Federal Reserve monetary policy decision.

data.title: Currency
data.content: The dollar index strengthened above 107 on Friday, positioning it for a 1% gain for the week, marking its best weekly performance in a month. These gains come as markets have already priced in a 25-basis point rate cut from the Federal Reserve next week, though the outlook for 2025 remains uncertain. Data released on Thursday showed the headline producer price index rose more than expected, while the core index slowed in line with forecasts. Additionally, initial jobless claims unexpectedly rose to a nearly two-month high of 242K, well above the anticipated 220K. Markets are currently assigning a 96% probability that the Fed will implement a quarter-point rate cut at next week's meeting. The dollar also gained against the euro and Swiss franc following rate cuts from the European Central Bank and Swiss National Bank on Thursday.
data.summary: The dollar index strengthened above 107 on Friday, positioning it for a 1% gain for the week, marking its best weekly performance in a month. These gains come as markets have already priced in a 25-basis point rate cut from the Federal Reserve next week, though the outlook for 2025 remains uncertain. Markets are currently assigning a 96% probability that the Fed will implement a quarter-point rate cut at next week's meeting. The dollar also gained against the euro and Swiss franc following rate cuts from the European Central Bank and Swiss National Bank on Thursday.
data.author: Currency

data.title: Nasdaq Futures Rise
data.content: Nasdaq 100 futures rose 0.5% on Friday, buoyed by a surge in shares of Broadcom, a key index component, which rallied 15% in after-hours trading. The chipmaker reported a 220% increase in artificial intelligence revenue for the year and issued stronger-than-expected revenue guidance for its fiscal first quarter. RH also posted impressive gains, jumping 18% after providing robust revenue growth projections for the upcoming period. In contrast, U.S. equities faced pressure in regular trading on Thursday. The Dow dropped 0.53%, the S&P 500 fell 0.54%, and the Nasdaq Composite tumbled 0.66%. A hotter-than-expected inflation report dampened market sentiment, with the November producer price index rising 0.4%, double the forecasted 0.2%. In individual stock moves, UnitedHealth Group slid another 3.3%, bringing its total loss to 14% since the death of its healthcare unit CEO. Adobe also plummeted 13.7% after issuing a weaker-than-expected outlook for 2025.

In individual stock moves, UnitedHealth Group slid another 3.3%, bringing its total loss to 14% since the death of its healthcare unit CEO. Adobe also plummeted 13.7% after issuing a weaker-than-expected outlook for 2025.

data.title: Stock Market
data.content: The S&P 500 and Nasdaq each closed 0.6% lower on Thursday as a hotter-than-expected U.S. inflation report weighed on market sentiment, with technology shares leading the decline. November's producer price index rose 0.4%, doubling forecasts of 0.2%, underscoring slow progress toward the Federal Reserve’s 2% inflation target. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 234 points, driven by a 3.3% decline in UnitedHealth Group, whose shares have plummeted 14% since the death of its healthcare unit CEO. Other blue-chip stocks, including Caterpillar (-2.1%), Home Depot (-1.7%), and Sherwin-Williams (-1.5%), also suffered losses. Among the tech leaders, Nvidia fell 1.4%, and Adobe plunged 13.6% after issuing a weaker-than-expected 2025 outlook. While markets remain near record highs, these declines highlight growing investor caution amid uneven sector performance and persistent economic uncertainty as the year-end nears.

data.title: Stock Market
data.content: US stocks fell on Thursday afternoon, with the S&P 500 losing 0.3% and the Nasdaq and Dow Jones each dropping around 0.4%, the latter marking its fifth consecutive decline. A hotter-than-expected November producer price index raised concerns about persistent inflation, tempering hopes for swift interest rate cut guidance from the Federal Reserve. The PPI rose 0.4%, exceeding expectations of 0.2%, signaling ongoing wholesale price pressures that could complicate the Fed's path to its 2% inflation target. Tech stocks led the losses, with Nvidia falling over 1% and Adobe tumbling more than 13% on a weak revenue outlook. Traders also assessed a sharp rise in initial jobless claims to 242K, nearly a two-month high and above the 220K forecast, bolstering expectations for a Fed rate cut next week. The odds of a 25bps reduction in the fed funds rate currently stand at 94%.
data.summary: US stocks fell on Thursday afternoon, with the S&P 500 losing 0.3% and the Nasdaq and Dow Jones each dropping around 0.4%, the latter marking its fifth consecutive decline. Traders also assessed a sharp rise in initial jobless claims to 242K, nearly a two-month high and above the 220K forecast, bolstering expectations for a Fed rate cut next week.
